snippet: Syria held parliamentary elections on Monday, which the government billed as a step toward reform and the opposition dismissed as a farce that ignored demands for real political change.
abstract: Syrian government holds parliamentary elections, calling them an important step toward reform, while virtually ignoring public demands for sweeping democratic change that have rocked the country for 14 months; opposition calls the elections a sham. Photo (M)i

byline.original: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR; Hwaida Saad contributed reporting from Beirut, and an employee of The New York Times from Damascus, Syria

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon -- The Syrian government held parliamentary elections on Monday, calling them an important step toward reform, while virtually ignoring public demands for sweeping democratic change that have rocked the country for the past 14 months. The opposition called the elections a sham, and the vote was both widely boycotted and mocked across the country.

headline.main: Syrians Vote in Election Dismissed by Foes as a Farce

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: MIDDLE EAST AND NORTH AFRICA UNREST (2010- )
